Construct the required quantities for the formation of the Z vector, for a given density component, given the kernel derivatives wrt U variables. 

See J. Chem. Theory Comput. 2011, 7, 3097–3104 (modified e derived for Scalar and Magn).


\begin{DoxyParams}[1]{Parameters}
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em dentyp} & Type of 1PDM (SCALAR, \{M\+\_\+k\}). \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em is\+GGA} & Whether to include \mbox{\hyperlink{classChronusQ_1_1GGA}{GGA}} contributions. \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em NPts} & Number of points in the batch\\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em VRho\+Eval} & Pointer to the first partial derivative of the energy per unit volume in terms of the dens\mbox{[}+,-\/\mbox{]}.\\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em Vgamma\+Eval} & Pointer to the first partial derivative of the energy per unit volume in terms of the gammas\mbox{[}++,+-\/,--\mbox{]}.\\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ out}}  & {\em Zrho\+Var1} & Factors to multiply the scalar density for particular Z matrix \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ out}}  & {\em Zgamma\+Var1} & Factors to multiply the gradient scalar density for particular Z matrix \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ out}}  & {\em Zgamma\+Var2} & Factors to multiply the gradient particular mag density for particular Z matrix\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
Note we build 2 $\ast$ X in Eq 12 and 13 in J. Chem. Theory Comput. 2011, 7, 3097–3104. Since ZMAT \mbox{\hyperlink{classChronusQ_1_1LDA}{LDA}} part needs to factor 0.\+5 for the symmetrization procedure (see Eq. 15 1st term on r.\+h.\+s) Zrho\+Var1 part does not need this factor anymore.

The 0.\+5 factors come from the chain rules.

On the other hand since we are building 2 $\ast$ X, we factor already in both Zgamma\+Var1 and Zgamma\+Var2 (since there is 0.\+5 coming from the chain rules as well for the \mbox{\hyperlink{classChronusQ_1_1GGA}{GGA}} terms). Note there is still a factor of 2 that is included already in the Grad SCALAR/\+Mz (the one required in Eq 17).

Notes. The Zrho\+Var1 multiply the \mbox{\hyperlink{classChronusQ_1_1LDA}{LDA}} contribution to ZMAT

Notes. The Zgamma\+Var1 multiply the \mbox{\hyperlink{classChronusQ_1_1GGA}{GGA}} Del SCALAR contribution to ZMAT Notes. The Zgamma\+Var2 multiply the \mbox{\hyperlink{classChronusQ_1_1GGA}{GGA}} Del Mk contribution to ZMAT Here is the caller graph for this function\+:

Sorts a vector of eigenvalues relative to a particular value in a standard way. 

Assigns a standard ordering for both real and complex eigenvalues relative to their distance from a provided shift value. Initially sorts by magnitude of the distance, then by the real part of the distance to ensure a consistant ordering between conjugate pairs if they exist.

Assigns a standard ordering for both real and complex eigenvalues. Initially sorts by eigenvalue magnitude, then by the real part to ensure a consistant ordering between conjugate pairs if they exist. Also sorts the eigenvectors corresponding to the eigenvalues in place.

Sorts a vector of eigenvalues and a corresponding matrix of eigenvectors relative to a particular value in a standard way.

Templated function which diagonalizes a general (non-\/hermetian) matrix which is general to real and complex. Handles memory managment internally through a \mbox{\hyperlink{classChronusQ_1_1CQMemManager}{CQMem\+Manager}} object. Always returns complex eigenvalues for generality.

{\footnotesize\ttfamily template$<$typename T $>$ \\
int Chronus\+Q\+::get\+LWork (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{std\+::function$<$ void(T $\ast$, int $\ast$)$>$}]{func }\end{DoxyParamCaption})}



Helper function to obtain optimal LAPACK workspace dimension. 


\begin{DoxyParams}[1]{Parameters}
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em func} & Function which returns the optimal workspace \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
Optimal workspace dimension
\end{DoxyReturn}
z.\+B.

For DSYEV, the optimal workspace may be queried by passing LWORK = -\/1 (like all LAPACK functions). The parameter list for DSYEV is given as

void dsyev\+\_\+(char $\ast$\+JOBZ, char $\ast$\+UPLO, int $\ast$\+N, double $\ast$\+A, int $\ast$\+LDA,    double $\ast$\+W, double $\ast$\+WORK, int $\ast$\+LWORK, int $\ast$\+INFO);

To use this function to query the workspace, we may bind a set of arguments to the funcion (i.\+e. the parameters from a DSYEV envocation)

auto test = std\+::bind(dsyev,\&\+JOBZ,\&\+UPLO,\&\+N,\+A,\&\+LDA,\+W,   std\+::placeholders\+::\+\_\+1, std\+::placeholders\+::\+\_\+2,\&\+INFO);

And then get the worksapce

int LWORK = get\+LWork$<$double$>$(test); \mbox{\Hypertarget{namespaceChronusQ_ad66491ad088347dba47e1bf863628099}\label{namespaceChronusQ_ad66491ad088347dba47e1bf863628099}}

Smart wrapper around DSYEV and ZHEEV depending on context.

Add two (sub) matricies together. 

C = ALPHA $\ast$ op(\+A) + BETA $\ast$ op(\+B)


\begin{DoxyParams}[1]{Parameters}
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em TRANSA} & Defines op(\+A) \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em TRANSB} & Defines op(\+B) \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em M} & Number of rows in A and B \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em N} & Number of columns in A and B \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em ALPHA} & Scaling parameter which scales A \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em A} & Raw storage of the matrix A \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em \mbox{\hyperlink{classChronusQ_1_1LDA}{LDA}}} & Leading dimension of the matrix A \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em BETA} & Scaling parameter which scales B \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em B} & Raw storage of the matrix B \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em LDB} & Leading dimension of the matrix B \\
\hline
 & {\em \mbox{[}in/out\mbox{]}} & C Raw storage of the matrix C \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em LDC} & Leading dimension of the matrix C\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
op(\+A) and op(\+B) are defined the same as for GEMM operations with the addition the \textquotesingle{}R\textquotesingle{} will yield a pure conjugation (not conjugate transpose as in \textquotesingle{}C\textquotesingle{}) of a complex matrix

\begin{DoxyWarning}{Warning}
It is only possible for A/C or B/C to overlap if op(\+A) or op(\+B) are \textquotesingle{}N\textquotesingle{}, respectively. 
\end{DoxyWarning}

Multiply a series of matrices on the right with a given matrix. 

C\+\_\+i = \textbackslash{}alpha AB\+\_\+i for all B\+\_\+i in V

If the matrices are of different dimension, the A matrix is assumed to be tensored with the appropriate identity matrix to give the dimension of the A matrix.

e.\+g.

B = $\vert$ a b $\vert$ A = $\vert$ e $\vert$ -\/-\/\texorpdfstring{$>$}{>} C = $\vert$ ea eb $\vert$ $\vert$ c d $\vert$ $\vert$ ec ed $\vert$

\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em KA} & Number of columns in A \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em KB} & Number of rows in B. Must be a multiple of KA. \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em alpha} & Scalar in multiplication \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em A} & Pointer to A \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em \mbox{\hyperlink{classChronusQ_1_1LDA}{LDA}}} & Leading dimension of A \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em V} & Vector of pointers to B matrices \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em LDB} & Leading dimension of B \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ in}}  & {\em SCR} & Scratch space, at least M$\ast$N. Only referenced if any B\+\_\+i is the same as any C\+\_\+i \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ out}}  & {\em U} & Vector of pointers to C matrices. Can be the same as V. \\
\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ out}}  & {\em LDC} & Leading dimension of C \\
\hline
